awd_titl_txt: Bilateral BBSRC-NSF/BIO: ABI Innovation: Modeling protein interactions to interpret genetic variation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will connect information about the DNA sequence of genes to what that means for the function of the proteins that the genes make. Structural information on proteins and how proteins interact is essential for understanding the effects of genetic variation on the function of cells. Because of all the large DNA sequencing projects, we have huge amounts of information on DNA changes that lead to changes in the building blocks of proteins (the amino acids) for all types of organisms, but understanding how this affects protein and cell function is much farther behind. This project will provide new and improved methods for determining how proteins are folded, and how they interact with other proteins, which affects how cells behave. This research will allow researchers to connect structural properties of all the proteins occurring in a single organism to changes in appearance, behavior, and responses to the environment of that organism. By publishing the results through Web-available databases the total effect on the organism from the structural and interaction changes will be available to other researchers and the public. The long-term research goals are to understand the molecular properties that drive life processes, and to choose changes that will result in making the intended product having the expected function in biotechnology applications.  The research outcomes will be included in graduate and undergraduate courses. Minority students, women, undergraduates, including those at primarily teaching institutions, and high-school students will be involved in different parts of the research. The participants of the project present their results at scientific conferences.

The project will result in an integrated approach for large-scale prediction of protein structures and their association. A database of predicted structures and complexes for model organisms will be established upon which genetic variants will be mapped and their phenotypic effect assessed. The research objectives are: (1) to develop high-throughput structure-based methods to predict interactions of experimentally determined and modeled proteins; (2) to develop advanced methodology for high throughput modeling of individual proteins; (3) to generate genome-wide database of protein  structures and protein-protein complexes for model organisms; and (4) to assess phenotypic effects of genetic variation. Approaches will be developed to discriminate non-interacting from interacting proteins, and to model the structures of protein-protein complexes, based on similarity to experimentally determined protein-protein complexes and on properties of the intermolecular energy landscape. A novel approach to fold detection will extend the number of proteins that can be modeled. A pipeline will be developed to integrate protein structure prediction with the prediction of protein complexes, and use structure-based approaches to predict the effects of SAVs. This collaborative project combines highly complementary areas of expertise of the US team, on high-throughput modeling of protein interactions, and the UK team, on protein structure prediction and SAV effects. The results of the project will be available at
http://vakser.compbio.ku.edu and http://www.sbg.bio.ic.ac.uk.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit. The focus of the project was on development of new methodologies for modeling of proteins and protein interactions (protein docking) and structure-based assessment of genetic mutations. For the development of docking approaches based on similarity to experimentally determined complexes (templates), we performed comparative analysis based on different template libraries (full protein structure vs. protein-protein interface vs. protein sequence). Significant improvement was observed when the same template was selected by different methods. Combining methodologies, accurate models were generated for 90% of the complexes. To explore the utility of structural motifs in protein domains for protein-protein docking, we performed a systematic comparison of such motifs with protein-protein interfaces. The results showed that physicochemical characteristics, such as amino acid composition, residue-residue contact preferences, and hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity distributions, are similar in both, but characteristics that reflect the evolutionary pressure, such as structural composition and packing, are largely different. The results contribute to better understanding of the ways to dock proteins.

For scoring of the predicted docking configurations, we developed a semianalytical approach to contact potentials. Energies were derived by maximizing the probability of observing native sequences in a set of proteins. The potentials yielded significant improvement in docking and recapitulated experimentally determined stability changes upon point mutations and protein-protein binding affinities. Characterization of protein function further improved the scoring of the template-based docking. Structurally similar interfaces showed greater variability of function than the whole protein. Most structure clusters comprised more than one sequence sub-cluster, suggesting presence of distantly related sequences in the same structural interface motif. The results significantly improved template-based docking in cases of weak target/template structure similarity.

Publicly available results of biological research provide constraints on the binding mode, which can be essential for the docking. Our text-mining tool, which extracts binding site residues from the publicly available abstracts and full-text papers, was successfully applied to protein docking. A further development of the tool utilized natural language processing for analyzing the context of the residue occurrence. The results showed significant improvement of docking by using the constraints generated by the advanced text mining. For structural refinement of the predicted complexes, a large-scale analysis of conformational changes upon binding was performed. The results determined the scope of the conformational change, providing important guidelines for the refinement protocol.

New protein structure prediction approach developed by the UK team improved the accuracy of the protein models. Protein structures in the human proteome generated by the high-throughput modeling were used by the US team to dock protein-protein complexes incorporated in the GWYRE resource. A new approach, applicable to experimental and predicted structures, assesses whether an amino acid variation is structurally damaging.

Because of limitations of the experimental techniques, most proteins in genome-wide studies will be models of limited accuracy. The US and UK teams conducted a large-scale systematic study on application of docking to protein models in a broad range of structural accuracy, in a real-case scenario, when the actual accuracy of the model is unknown and can only be estimated. The results showed that template-based docking is less sensitive to modeling inaccuracies than the free docking. The study provided practical guidelines for combining modeling of individual proteins with modeling of their complexes in genome-wide studies. A prototype of the public resource implementing the new approaches and datasets was developed.

Broader impacts. The results were utilized by the research community in studies of protein interactions and phenotypic effects of genetic mutations. The developed procedures, and the outcomes of the project were included in the PI’s Bioinformatics course. Minority students and women were involved in different parts of the project. The PI’s laboratory is one of the centers of computational biology research and education at the University of Kansas, involving faculty, research staff, postdoctoral fellows, and students from the University of Kansas, other universities (including minority serving institutions) and high schools. The project participants presented their results at top international conferences. Among them, the PI’s bi-annual Modeling of Protein Interactions meeting, which brings together world top experts on the broad subject of this proposal. The meeting provides a unique opportunity for students and postdocs to prominently present their research and to interact with the leaders of the field. The PI's group continued their contributions to the community-wide efforts to structurally characterize protein interactome, such as Critical Assessment of Predicted Interactions (CAPRI). The project enhanced the research capabilities in fundamental biological research, biotechnology, and other areas of molecular biology and genomics.


Last Modified: 12/31/2020
Modified by: Ilya A Vakser
